subject: Simplify creation/cleanup of testenvs
commit_message:
Simplify creation/cleanup of testenvs

In I1b10abda0209f1c58c6c2612542d8a6cd42628e8, the way cleanup-env had to
second-guess what testenv might have done (and even then, couldn't
guarantee that it made the right choice and had to accept an explicit
override for the seed VM's name) caused a significant amount of
confusion.

Thinking about this overnight, I came to believe that the cause of this
confusion is the fact that two unrelated parameters to
devtest_testenv.sh are being entangled in the choice of name for the
seed_vm. Many people who looked at cleanup-env made the assumption that
if "-n N" is passed to _testenv.sh, the seed name will be seed_N.

This seems to me as though it's a reasonable assumption, and tweaking
the code to behave this way makes it simpler.

To the best of my knowledge, the -n and -b options were added to
_testenv to support CI, which always uses them together. This change
should make no difference to CI.

This change *may* affect people who previously used -n without -b, but
as I don't see how they'd have a working setup with >1 environments all
competing for the single VM named "seed", I don't believe this is a
problem.

subject: Record and log reason for dhcp agent resync
commit_message:
Record and log reason for dhcp agent resync

A dhcp resync can be triggered at a number of points, but the actual
resync is done asynchronously by a helper thread.  This means by the
time the resync happens, it's hard to establish what actually caused
it.

There have been a number of problems in production systems that cause
excessive resyncs.  One is a ipv6/dnsmasq issue (rhbz#1077487) and
another is db corruption with duplicate entries [1].  The resync
triggers a whole lot of logs itself, so it becomes very unclear how to
establish any causality.

This change keeps track of what triggered the resync with some helpful
information.  We add a schedule_resync() function to to replace a
explicit set of needs_resync which tracks why it was called.

[1] The logs will contain output like "DBDuplicateEntry
(IntegrityError) (1062, "Duplicate entry
'6d799c6a-7a09-4c1e-bb63-7d30fd052c8a-d3e3ac5b-9962-428a-a9f8-6b2' for
key 'PRIMARY'") ..." in this case

Closes-Bug: #1294445

subject: Get info for volume backed snapshot from an instance.
commit_message:
Get info for volume backed snapshot from an instance.

Current implementation of creating snapshot from a volume
backed instance has some weakness.

1 In instance booted from image case it uses the image info as
the template to create a new image. But original image contains
many attributes and possibly properties are harmful or not
needed for the new image. For example id, checksum.
Current implementation has to clean harmful attributes instead
of to explicity set significant ones. Also it transfer
not needed attributes to the new image, in the result
the last one looks oddly.

2 In instance booted from volume case it uses image metadata
stored in the volume. But unlike original image info
this metadata stores image attributes not hierarchically.
Since no transformation is provided, some critical attributes
are handled as image properties and are lost.
For example disk_format. In the result we have bad image with
many oddly properties.

3 Public method of Nova Compute API cann't create snapshot
unless appropriate image metadata is provided to it. But this
is not consistently. For example we cann't create a raw snapshot
from an ami instance. A caller should prepare image meta by
instance info, and then API method prepares a rest of image meta
by instance info as well.
In theory the public method should make a snapshot of
an instance, gathering all sufficient instance dependend info by
itself.

When current implementation was first introduced
(Essex milestone, EC2 layer), no other soures of image meta
existed. But later instance system metadata was founded, and now
it keeps all original image metadata is needed to create
a snapshot. This metadata is copied from an image or from image
metadata stored in a boot volume.

In this changeset only instance system metadata is used
to create a volume backed instance snapshot.

Change-Id: I7106ec0dd26ccede276da7945362677d00e5e33c
Closes-Bug: #1322157
Related-Bug: #1322195

Fix InstanceActionEvent traceback parameter not serializable

The change to use InstanceActionEvent in compute.utils.EventReporter
changed the order of how things are done. Before, traceback info were
converted to a string before being sent to the conductor. Now, since

also-affected but currently-unused finish_with_failure() instance

subject: teach get_installed_ovs_klm_version about vermagic:
commit_message:
teach get_installed_ovs_klm_version about vermagic:

On Fedora 20, neutron-openvswitch-agent fails to start with the
following error:

  neutron.plugins.openvswitch.agent.ovs_neutron_agent SystemError: Unable
  to determine kernel version for Open vSwitch with VXLAN support. To use
  VXLAN tunnels with OVS, please ensure that the version is 1.10 or newer!

In neutron/agent/linux/ovs_lib.py, the code is attempting to determine
the installed version of the openvswitch module by calling:

  modinfo openvswitch

It's looking for a line containing "version: ", but "modinfo" produces
no such line; the output looks like this:

  filename:
  /lib/modules/3.11.10-301.fc20.x86_64/kernel/net/openvswitch/openvswitch.ko
  license: GPL
  description: Open vSwitch switching datapath
  depends: gre
  intree: Y
  vermagic: 3.11.10-301.fc20.x86_64 SMP mod_unload
  signer: Fedora kernel signing key
  sig_key: 03:59:1D:C5:7A:69:07:41:40:1A:1C:20:2E:2B:3D:9F:4F:ED:2A:0E
  sig_hashalgo: sha256

This patch teaches get_installed_ovs_klm_version about the "vermagic: "
line, which also provides the desired information.

Change-Id: I6b84657d58cef09cca9ae3162e3ea2adbef56034
Closes-bug: #1326907

servers with the parameter, but sometimes we could not get it and the

after the DB record creation, the record is not updated and "get a

subject: Refactor split_by_op and split_by_datatype
commit_message:
Refactor split_by_op and split_by_datatype

split_by_op was returning data against which further error checking was
then required. This change moves that error handling inside the method
and simplifies the regular expression so that it splits (greedily) on
the first operator it finds. If the split is not possible, it is
a ValueError. If the field or value are empty, that is a ValueError.

Both split_by_op and split_by_datatype were doing a findall() where
a match() and split() do the right job and more efficiently.

Regular expression compilation has been moved to the module level
to insure they need only be compiled once. Operator keys must be
sorted by length to ensure the point at which the split happens is
most greedy. Using a split keeps the regex short and removes any
statements about the left and right hand sides of the operator.

Tests added to cover the method more completely, including testing
for corner cases such as single character field or values or
operators showing up in unexpected locations. 'string' variable
renamed to 'query' and 'query_value' to avoid confusion. Named parameters
on string substitution for clarity.

Note that the tests which do self.assertRaises could more explicitly
check the exception with self.assertRaisesRegexp but that would
break compatibility with Python 2.6.

The roles/profiles pattern is a way to combine ceph manifests into
functional units:

Profiles combine multiple manifest to provide a single service. For
example a ceph monitor server needs the repository, packages,

Roles define sets of profiles to configure a specific server. For

* params: extracts the configuration from hiera

The sed command (line 138) responsible for setting the database

subject: Fix the way Apache site configuration files are used, to improve OS portability
commit_message:
Fix the way Apache site configuration files are used, to improve OS portability

On Ubuntu 14.04, the site configuration file must have a .conf suffix for a2ensite and a2dissite to
recognise it. a2ensite and a2dissite ignore the .conf suffix used as parameter. The default sites'
files are 000-default.conf and default-ssl.conf.

On Ubuntu 12.04, the site configuration file may have any format, as long as it is in
/etc/apache2/sites-available/. a2ensite and a2dissite need the entire file name to work. The default
sites' files are default and default-ssl.

On Fedora, any file in /etc/httpd/conf.d/ whose name ends with .conf is enabled.

On RHEL and CentOS, things should hopefully work as in Fedora.

This change puts all distribution-related site configuration file name differences in lib/apache and
the other services gets the file name for its sites using the new exported function
apache_site_config_for <sitename>.

It also makes Fedora disabled sites use the .conf.disabled suffix instead of removing the .conf from
the file name.

The table below summarizes what should happen on each distribution:
+----------------------+--------------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+
| Distribution         | File name          | Site enabling command    | Site disabling command   |
+----------------------+--------------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+
| Ubuntu 12.04         | site               | a2ensite site            | a2dissite site           |
| Ubuntu 14.04         | site.conf          | a2ensite site            | a2dissite site           |
| Fedora, RHEL, CentOS | site.conf.disabled | mv site.conf{.disabled,} | mv site.conf{,.disabled} |
+----------------------+--------------------+--------------------------+--------------------------+

Change-Id: Ia2ba3cb7caccb6e9b65380f9d51d9d21180b894e
Closes-bug: #1313765
